subject: RE: [junit] Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: Hi David, FDA requirements vary from project to project but for the Software development parts, they come down to outlining the process you will follow and
messageBody:
Hi David,

FDA requirements vary from project to project but for the
Software development parts, they come down to outlining the
process you will follow and showing that you followed it.
Of course, the actual implementation of the requirements
is significantly influenced by the individual the FDA
assigns to examine your project.

I have worked on several projects and none of them gave
the unit tests to the FDA examiners. We did indicate that
100% passing unit tests were part of our development
methodology but that's as far as it went. OTOH, we ran
full system acceptance tests manually and provided reports
of them to the FDA in reproducible form - that is all
the inputs and outputs specified as the O.P. wants
to do with a log. Reproducible is a watchword in this
industry.

I've heard of people automating these acceptance tests
with FIT - in fact I know Ward did it for some clients.
Note however that these are a different sort of
"acceptance tests" from those we talk about in XP. In
fact, with one company, I had to come up with a
different name for XP-style acceptance tests, since
"we have no authority to accept anything." :-)

It seems to me that making unit test results available
on anything but an audit basis will lead to a lot of
project overhead. In many companies, the developers
have little influence over the promises made to the
FDA as part of a certification plan, so it may turn
out to be necessary to do it at this level. But if
you can influence it to only turn over system,
acceptance or integration tests, life may be easier.

Charlie

> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

>
> David Saff
>
> On Wed, Mar 11, 2009 at 3:16 PM, Gilles Scokart
> <gscokart@...> wrote:
> > I was about to ask if it wouldn't it be suffisent to have a report
> > with only Pass/Failure stored with the sources of the test (without
> > which "Smith" = "Smith" in a report doesn't have any meaning).
> >
> > But actually I found one utility.  By tracing every
> assertion that is
> > checked, you can validate that the assertion that are written into
> > your test are really executed, and that there is no bug in
> your unit
> > test that make the assertion skipped silently.
> >
> > If that's the reason for such report, maybe you can suggest
> that the
> > report is :
> > - Test ID Status
> > - Source code
> > - code coverage report of your unit test
> >
> >
> > But it is true that with regulations and laws, you can hardly argue
> > anything...
> >
> >
> > Gilles Scokart
> >
> >
> > 2009/3/11 rsgmxw <markwilhelm@...>
> >
> >>   One thing about the "logging of assertions" is reporting on the
> >> Actual/Observed results. I work at a company that makes Medical
> >> Devices. The FDA, as we're told by QA, requires the
> deposition of all
> >> tests. So even Pass'ing tests must have their actual
> results reported
> >> on. We do this currently with manual/human tests.
> >>
> >> If the report could say something like:
> >> Test ID Status Expected Actual
> >> 123 Pass Smith Smith
> >> 456 Pass Value > 10 12
> >> 789 Fail Value = "abc" xyz
> >> ...
> >>
> >> This report would be stored (for many years) for audit purposes.
> >>
> >> Now being a newbie, maybe there is a way to do this I don't know
> >> about - but very useful.
> >>
> >> Mark
> >>
> >> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>,
> "toalexsmail"
> >> <toalexsmail@...> wrote:
> >> >
> >> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, Robert
> >> > Wenner
> >> <robert.wenner@> wrote:
> >> > >
> >> > > On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18, Cédric Beust wrote:
> >> > > > > If I have to go through umpteen thousand lines of
> log, I may
> >> > > > > as
> >> well
> >> > > > > test everything manually.
> >> > > >
> >> > > > Nobody says you have to, but the fact that your tests pass
> >> > > > doesn't guarantee that you are testing what you
> think you are testing.
> >> > >
> >> > > Well. If the log is important, I have to go through
> it, or I miss
> >> > > something important. If it is not important (and I
> don't have to
> >> > > go through it) I can skip it altogether. So what do
> you mean when
> >> > > you
> >> > say I
> >> > > don't have to go through it?
> >> > >
> >> >
> >> > I have read carefully all the posts so far and I tend to
> agree with
> >> > Robert. I am wonder whether I miss something important too.
> >> > I want to be clear, so I will take one step backward.
> What is the
> >> > MAIN purpose of JUnit? The answer is to be able to write
> AUTOMATIC
> >> > unit test. Unit test should be written is the correct
> way, that is
> >> > correctly design. This has nothing to do with logging.
> Making unit
> >> > test AUTOMATIC contradict using logging.
> >> >
> >> > <you can skip the this paragraph>
> >> > I want to step aside for a while. Let assume that you're
> not using
> >> > JUnit at all and write small main function to test. I
> don't want to
> >> > counter why you shouldn't do this, let focus on what
> tools you do
> >> > use in this approach. In the most cases you will add System.out
> >> > both to the code and to the main. If you're using C++, for
> >> > instance, you will use preprocessor to switch on or off these
> >> > output to the console. More advance option will be to
> use logging
> >> > mechanism and to change it configuration depends on the
> environment
> >> > your program run (that is to turn on many of your log statement
> >> > only in development). Everything is great until your program is
> >> > actually fails. Again, from the experience it is almost
> always the
> >> > case that existing System.outs are not enough, that you
> need more
> >> > information or you should add some more output early in
> the code.
> >> > So, in this point you have to option to run your program
> AGAIN with
> >> > debugger or to add more System.outs and to run it as is. In both
> >> > cases it can be the case that you should rerun your
> program again
> >> > (if you use debugger you could simply not pointed out when some
> >> > data changed and in the System.out case you can figure
> out that you need more System.outs).
> >> >
> >> > From the paragraph above one should conclude that when one write
> >> > unit test there is 2 different phases. First is to write
> them down
> >> > in the hope that everything will be ok (it doesn't mean,
> that you
> >> > design should be poor or you shouldn't supply
> appropriate messages
> >> > to assert statements etc) and the second phase is to rerun your
> >> > test if your test fails. Lets see how logging will help you.
> >> >
> >> > In the first phase I see the only purpose using logs is
> for 'sanity
> >> > check' that is to ensure that you actually test what
> your think is
> >> > you test. If you want to make something more than just 'sanity
> >> > check' you should write unit test to your unit test,
> that is pretty silly.
> >> > Moreover, you need to make such 'sanity check' only when you
> >> > actually write this test. For this purpose logging is
> appropriate approach, IMHO.
> >> >
> >> > In the second phase, when you rerun your unit test when
> it fails,
> >> > you should consider to add more assert statement and
> more clearly
> >> > diagnostic messages first. When you done and you don't
> see how to
> >> > improve the design (recall I consider that design is
> correct) you
> >> > can add log statement manually. But in this case they
> will not be
> >> > part of new mechanism, because no more asserts will be added. So
> >> > this new feature will not be in use!
> >> >
> >> > Using logging in the assert statement ONLY for 'sanity check' is
> >> > overkill, I think. As for me I make such 'sanity check' in the
> >> > following way. First of all, I use log4j MANUALLY that is as
> >> > addition to JUnit asserts. They don't duplicate what
> asserts does
> >> > they supply additional information, such as what assertion was
> >> > already done. In this case when assertion will fail afterwards I
> >> > can look on the log to see in what part of unit test it happened
> >> > and what tests passed. I go even further and use JDK 1.4 assert
> >> > statement to document precondition, postcondition and invariants
> >> > both in the code and in the unit test.
> >> >
> >> > The bottom line is that I see the sense using logs as a
> COMPLETION
> >> > to the JUnit and only for 'sanity check'. This use is not
> >> > duplicates JUnit assert statements and could be written manually.
> >> >
